ikigai_analysis_report.primary_ikigai: Digital account management / personal-security upkeep (practical everyday administration)
secondary_areas: Possible curiosity about ad/tech topics (uncertain — marketing content)

supporting_evidence.pattern: High proportion of personal/transactional emails (3 of 4 = 75%) indicating attention to personal accounts
examples: 3 personal engagement emails out of 4 total

supporting_evidence.pattern: Repeated security notifications for the same account (sign-in alerts) — consistent, concrete daily/periodic activity related to checking and maintaining account safety
examples: Subject: "New sign-in detected for your Microsoft account"

supporting_evidence.pattern: Presence of an ad tech message (The Trade Desk) that could indicate interest in technology/ads — however this is marketing content and excluded from core ikigai assessment, so treated as low-evidence
examples: Subject: "Google ad tech remedies trial: Explained" — from info@thetradedesk.com

supporting_evidence.pattern: No detected learning-frequency signals or active growth patterns in the personal emails

framework_dimensions.external_connection: Low-to-moderate — connection is functional (account providers) rather than social or community-based; external world appears primarily as service notifications.
framework_dimensions.active_engagement: Low — most items are passive receipts (alerts). There is potential for active engagement if the user regularly reviews and responds to account alerts, but evidence is limited.
framework_dimensions.emotional_meaning: Minimal evidence — transactional nature of messages suggests limited emotional/joyful attachment; no clear signs of activities that bring everyday delight.
framework_dimensions.voluntary_pursuit: Low — security alerts are system-generated rather than voluntary personal pursuits. The one ad-tech item is marketing and cannot be confidently classed as chosen interest.
framework_dimensions.everyday_joy: Not apparent — no small, specific daily activities expressing joy are visible in the email sample.
framework_dimensions.growth_orientation: Absent in the data — zero indicators of active learning, courses, or personal-development communications.

recommendations: Treat current pattern as administrative, not ikigai — if you want to surface authentic ikigai, track emails or actions that you proactively seek out (newsletters you open for pleasure, invitations you respond to enthusiastically, project updates you act on).

Convert passive notifications into an active practice: make a brief routine when a security alert arrives (review activity, update passwords if unfamiliar, note trends). That turns upkeep into a small, chosen ritual.
Create a simple folder/tag system to capture emails that genuinely spark curiosity or joy. Over 30 days, note which tagged emails you eagerly open — these will reveal authentic, repeat interests.

If ad/tech topics matter, deliberately subscribe to a small number of non-commercial learning sources (1–2 trustworthy blogs or short newsletters) and commit 10 minutes daily to read; this will create measurable learning frequency.

Introduce one small voluntary daily activity (eg, 10-minute walk, photo a day, short journaling) connected to external interaction. Mitsuhashi’s ikigai emphasizes everyday, active, voluntary pursuits — start with something concrete and observable.
Reduce marketing noise (filters, unsubscribes) so genuine personal-engagement emails stand out. More signal will improve identification of authentic ikigai patterns.

methodology.approach: Content-based filtering to identify authentic personal communications

framework_principles.external_over_internal: Connection to external world through personal choice
